ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained lots of valuable practice speaking, reading, and writing in Hebrew. I also learned quite a bit about the techniques of film analysis.
I learned more about Israeli cinema and greatly improved my reading, writing, and speaking skills in Hebrew.
Israeli movies and more hebrew skills
I learned how to analyze movies in Hebrew, improved my vocabulary and syntax and learned a lot about Israeli film.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was well-taught and the assignments were all helpful practice in reading, writing, and/or film analysis. I can't think of any specific improvements that should be made.
The format of the class allowed me lots of practice in discussing Israeli films, but sometimes the weekly writing assignments were less helpful.
Selection of films were always really engaging and discussions were always really engaging. Syllabus was a little disorganised as it changed a number of times throughout the semester.

Strengths: Format of class, films, blogs being completion grade allowing to explore writing skills

Weaknesses: Not a fan of the quizzes. Found them difficult to study for and not super relevant to the subject matter of israeli films and culture

The strengths of the course are that it gives a very thorough overview of Israeli film from the last two decades. Personally, I would have preferred to talk about some movies more in depth rather than watching and discussing as many as possible. Moreover, while we talked quite a bit about spelling towards the end of the course, I would have liked to receive more advice on academic writing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was run well- besides the fact that discussions were held over Zoom, the course didn't necessitate any major changes due to COVID.
The benefit of the course being virtual was that we had so many opportunities to meet with directors, writers, and others who contribute to Israeli cinema over Zoom.
Class being live was very important because it was a discussion based class. Do not think asynchronous class would have worked well with this class

I found the course to be very engaging despite the online format. Yes, there were some awkward silences, but Shiri always managed to break them gracefully. I really liked how Shiri shared her screen often because it helped me focus on the class. I don't think there is much to improve on in terms of online engagement.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES take this class! Shiri is a national treasure, remarkable in her commitment to shaping the course to what individual students need. (I've literally never had a professor that so reliably implemented feedback. That's really something that I didn't see a lot in any of my other classes, even if those professors were great in other aspects.) Naama, the TF, is also an absolute joy to talk to. This class will: improve your written and spoken Hebrew, make you deeply sad because of all the sad movies you watch, make you deeply happy because of the intellectual level of the discussion. This class will not: make you incredibly stressed (there's a bunch of work but Shiri is very nice about extensions etc). My year the class was an even mix of heritage speakers and students that learned Hebrew at Yale, but I think it didn't really generate too much inequality, because people were simply good at different things. But everyone had interesting approaches to film analysis!
Yes, definitely! Whether you are a serious film enthusiast or just trying to polish your Hebrew, watching movies provides an enjoyable and interesting way to accomplish these goals.

I would recommend this course if you are willing to take the time to watch one or two Hebrew movies every week and spend a substantial amount of time thinking about them, writing about them, and discussing them.

Yes. It is a demanding L5 course. If you are flexible to changes in course structure and are willing to put in the time (at least 1 film per week, discussion post, extra events,etc), then this is a fun class to take.
I would recommend the class to people who want to learn more about israeli film or improve hebrew in an interesting way
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to an L5 Hebrew speaker, particularly to those interested in film.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also attended a few special events involving discussions with prominent figures in Israeli film.
Virtual seminars twice a week and virtual discussion sections once every two weeks
N/A
Virtual seminar where we discussed Israeli movies
